text: the World Health Organization calls it
an extraordinary event the most severe
Ebola outbreak ever and it says there
must be a coordinated international
response to stop and reverse its spread
the committee's conclusions and my
decisions are a clear call for
international solidarity countries
affected to date simply do not have the
capacity to manage the an outbreak of
this size and complexity on their own
the official statistics say 932 people
have died so far and that number will
rise Guinea Liberia and Sierra Leone are
the countries most affected in Liberia
troops at roadblocks trying to halt the
spread of Ebola the whao wants all the
affected countries to declare national
emergencies but they've been plagued by
civil unrest their health services are
weak and inexperienced and here in
Guinea a sick man is left to lie in the
street for hours
the w-h-o says fear both in the
countries already affected and in the
wider world is one of the major
challenges so it's not calling for a
general ban on international travel or
trade all governments need to be
vigilant and ready it suggests but the
main focus of concern remains West
Africa the outbreak will definitely be
brought under control but when that will
occur I don't think that any of us can
second-guess this is an immensely
challenging difficult and I think a
little bit unpredictable outbreak the
affected countries urgently need more
specialist equipment and trained
personnel but with no proven vaccine
should international aid also include
experimental drugs I think there's a
very good humanitarian case for using
these drugs but we don't really know
enough about whether they'll work or how
they work to be sure we can rely on them
and it's also going to take a
considerable amount of time to make
enough of these drugs to treat affected
people the w-h-o itself has limited
resources it wants its move now to
galvanize governments and agencies in
the affected region and
beyond Nick child's BBC news
